fields.name: location_information_header
fields.content: 1. Your property

fields.name: location_why
fields.content: At the end of this survey you will be able to hide your contact information and location information or voluntarily choose to make it public for the VSP report.

fields.name: drag_map_info
fields.content: Please drag and zoom the map to center the pin on your property.

fields.name: address
fields.prompt: Search by address
fields.placeholder: Your address will never be shared

fields.name: wetlands_header
fields.content: 2. Wetland Areas

fields.name: wetlands_information
fields.content:
Description

Wetland areas are inundated or saturated by surface water or groundwater.

Appearance on map

fields.name: private-property_on_wetlands
fields.prompt: Are there any wetlands?

fields.name: wetlands_disclaimer
fields.content: The wetlands data is supplied by US Fish & Wildlife Service through their National Wetlands Inventory. Their maps are prepared from the analysis of high altitude imagery. Wetlands are identified based on vegetation, visible hydrology and geography. A margin of error is inherent in the use of imagery. Landowners interested in an on-the-ground assessment to confirm the presence of these mapped wetlands for the purposes of the Voluntary Stewardship Program are encouraged to contact the KCCD.

fields.name: frequently_flooded_header
fields.content: 3. Frequently Flooded Areas

fields.name: frequently_flooded_information
fields.content:
Description

Frequently flooded areas are subject to a 1% or greater chance of flooding every year.

Appearance on map

fields.name: private-property_on_frequently_flooded
fields.prompt: Are there any frequently flooded areas?

fields.name: frequently_flooded_disclaimer
fields.content: Frequently flood areas on this map are a combination of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) flood insurance rate map (FIRM) designated 100- year floodplain and floodway.

fields.name: geologic_hazard_header
fields.content: 4. Severe Geologic Hazard Areas

fields.name: geologic_hazard_information
fields.content:
Description

Severe geologic hazard areas are susceptible to erosion, sliding, earthquakes, and other events.

Appearance on map

fields.name: private-property_on_geologic_hazard
fields.prompt: Are there any severe geologic hazard areas?

fields.name: geologic_hazard_disclaimer
fields.content: The data displayed on this map includes soil types with a slope of 25% or greater as an approximation of areas where geologic hazards may exist. For more detailed information on geologic hazards contact the KCCD.

fields.name: critical_aquifer_header
fields.content: 5. Critical Aquifer Recharge Areas

fields.name: critical_aquifer_information
fields.content:
Description

Critical aquifer recharge areas have a critical effect on aquifers used for potable water.

Appearance on map

fields.name: private-property_on_critical_aquifer
fields.prompt: Are there any critical aquifer recharge areas?

fields.name: critical_aquifer_disclaimer
fields.content: Kittitas County does not currently have a designated critical aquifer recharge area, however wellhead protection for public water systems is an important component of the larger effort to protect aquifers used for potable water. The data shown here are the Group A and Group B wells with a 600 foot to 10,000 foot buffer depending on the number of connections allowed. For additional information on Critical Aquifer Recharge Areas, contact the KCCD.

fields.name: fish_wildlife_habitat_header
fields.content: 6. Fish & Wildlife Habitat

fields.name: fish_wildlife_habitat_information
fields.content:
Description

Fish & wildlife habitats are managed to maintain populations of fish and wildlife. Zoom the map to explore which species live in your area.

Appearance on map
Priority habitats: areas with unique or significant value to many species
Fish-bearing waterways: creeks and rivers that are priority habitats for Summer Steelhead, Spring Chinook, Coho, Dolly Varden/Bull Trout, Westslope Cutthroat, Mountain Sucker, or Rainbow Trout

fields.name: private-property_on_fish_wildlife_habitat
fields.prompt: Are there any fish & wildlife conservation areas?

fields.name: fish_wildlife_habitat_disclaimer
fields.content: The Fish and Wildlife Conservation areas are provided by the Washington State Department of Fish and Wildlife’s Priority Habitats and Species (PHS) Program. For more specific information on habitats or species on or near your property, contact the KCCD.

fields.name: other_practices_header
fields.content: 13. Other VSP Practices

fields.name: other_practices
fields.prompt: Use this space to describe any other stewardship practices you have completed. If you can, please include approximate acreage or footage and approximate start date:
fields.placeholder: Description, acreage or footage, and approximate start date:

fields.name: additional_info_header
fields.content: 14. Almost completed!

fields.name: additional_info
fields.content:
Thank you for taking the time to voluntarily report your stewardship practices.

This page will determine how your information is shared. We will report all practices at the watershed scale, but if you are interested in having your project showcased you can give us permission below. Either way, we will be using your stewardship practice to capture how agriculture is protecting and/or restoring critical areas and maintaining the viability of agriculture.

fields.name: my_image
fields.prompt: Show your stewardship practices! Upload photos before, during, or after you implemented your stewardship practices:
fields.label: Upload photos

fields.name: practices_description
fields.prompt: Add a description of your stewardship practices!

fields.name: private
fields.prompt: Would you be willing to share your stewardship story with the public? Checking "yes" below will place a pin on the map upon submission and your stewardship actions will be visible to the public.

fields.placeholder: Your phone number will never be shared

content: Your Garfield County VSP Coordinators are interested in helping meet your stewardship goals.
Contact a local VSP Coordinator or for more information visit: www.garfieldcountyvsp.com.

Welcome Kittitas County Voluntary Stewards!

Get Started
The Kittitas County Voluntary Stewardship Program (VSP) is an innovative approach to reporting the protection of critical areas.
VSP is facilitated by the Kittitas County Conservation District (KCCD), who is designated as the Technical Service Provider for this program.
Click here to learn more about KCCD's services
Or, click Get Started to share your stewardship!
